terrain.primary: PA hilly gravel with cyclocross elements
terrain.surface: Gravel roads with cyclocross obstacles. Significant elevation with PA scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional PA event. Hilly terrain with cyclocross elements, moderate organization, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Iron Cross is a regional event in Pennsylvania—hilly terrain with cyclocross obstacles. The cyclocross elements and PA hills are appealing, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Pennsylvania provides good access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional PA gravel/cyclocross race with hilly terrain and technical elements. Worth it for PA/Northeast cyclists seeking a cyclocross-style gravel race. Not a destination race for national travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in PA/Northeast and want a cyclocross-style gravel race—yes, it's solid. If you're from out of region—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better PA events: Trans-Sylvania Epic. For similar cyclocross gravel events: other regional cyclocross races.

logistics.food: PA has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: PA hilly gravel with cyclocross obstacles.

suffering_zones.label: Late Hills
suffering_zones.desc: Final hilly sections with obstacles before finish.

guide_variables.race_terrain: PA hilly gravel with cyclocross elements

non_negotiables.why: PA hills with cyclocross obstacles require sustained effort.
Cyclocross obstacles require technical handling skills.
Hilly terrain with obstacles requires pacing discipline.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with hilly terrain and cyclocross obstacles.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup party at New Trail Brewing and clear start location at 423 East Central Ave keeps things simple. Race limit of 300 means no chaos at registration or start line. But vague timing details and no major airport access keeps this from being seamless — you'll figure it out, but it takes effort. As Selene Yeager puts it: "Right before we were going to come toward aid station #2, we asked a moto which way, and he said straight so we went straight. We went four miles off course."

length.explanation: Cole House notes the mental challenge: 'There was so much climbing — if you don't know how long it is mentally, you can kind of give up.' McCluskey didn't hit his groove until mile 22. The 60-mile distance with multiple options respects different ambitions without being a multi-day commitment. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Selene Yeager puts it: "Right before we were going to come toward aid station #2, we asked a moto which way, and he said straight so we went straight. We went four miles off course."

technicality.explanation: McCluskey describes 'wheels slipping on the wet leaves and rocks' before reaching the run-up — 'a wall of thick moss-covered loose rocks going straight up to the heavens.' Cole House won by gapping riders on singletrack: 'I just popped over those logs. That's where a mountain bike really paid off.' Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Brian Toone puts it: "There was so much climbing... The ATV trails were so fun on the descents. It was so fast."

elevation.explanation: Liz M reports 'over 7,000 feet of climbing' in 56 miles, including switchback sections with 'pitches of up to 9%' on old granite roads. The course features repeated hard climbing after the halfway point, and ends with what she calls a 'kick-in-the-chamois single-track section that goes STRAIGHT UP.' Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Brian Toone puts it: "There was so much climbing... The ATV trails were so fun on the descents. It was so fast."

climate.explanation: October conditions vary dramatically — McCluskey faced 'cold, steady autumn rain that continued all day' with wind 'pelting my face and pushing me side to side.' But the 2013 race featured 'perfect trail and weather conditions, with sunny skies and comfortable temperatures.' Mid-October in Pennsylvania means prepare for anything. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As McCluskey puts it: "Dark. Cold. The alarm went off at 4:45a. Ugh. Ok. Let's do this... 'How much' and 'what to wear' was the big question of the day."

altitude.explanation: Starting at South Williamsport around 600 feet elevation, this is sea-level racing. Zero altitude considerations affect performance — your fitness limitations are atmospheric, not geographic. Pennsylvania climbing is about gradient and duration, not thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: McCluskey navigates 'thick wet mud, with standing water ponds on the double track' before hitting technical singletrack. The run-up requires shouldering bikes up moss-covered rocks. Liz M describes the deep woods as 'mystical fairy land' during peak fall colors — this delivers terrain variety that defines adventure.

prestige.explanation: Claims 'North America's Original Gravel Race' with 22 years of history, but the competitive field remains regional. Cole House and Brian Toone battled for the 2013 win, yet there's no broader recognition or media coverage. Being first doesn't guarantee being famous — Iron Cross stays a Pennsylvania institution.

race_quality.explanation: The basics work — Liz M praises 'great snacks and awesome volunteers' at aid stations, plus the self-support option at checkpoint 2. But course marking isn't foolproof — Selene Yeager went four miles off-course following incorrect directions. Small-scale organization with regional execution standards. As Selene Yeager puts it: "Right before we were going to come toward aid station #2, we asked a moto which way, and he said straight so we went straight. We went four miles off course."

experience.explanation: Liz M describes registration including 'a free pint glass, a spiffy pair of socks, and a token for a free beer and dinner' at Stonehouse post-race. The packet pickup party at New Trail Brewing and Warren Holtzman cooking 'a few hundred pounds of pork' creates weekend value beyond just racing.

community.explanation: Larry's Tavern defines the spirit — McCluskey describes 'raucous roar of enthusiasm' as volunteers pass out 'beers, pickle/vodka shots and chunks of grilled venison' with 'a slap on the back.' Liz M notes the crew 'are all named Larry' and hand out official stickers. This is community theater at its finest. As McCluskey puts it: "I could hear the sound of Angus Young's guitar and smell of campfire. Then a yell of 'YEAH!! WOO!! ALRIGHT!!' With a raucous roar of enthusiasm, an unofficial stop at Larry's Tavern welcomed and cheer..."

field_depth.explanation: Evan McGregor finished 12th and earned an age group podium, suggesting modest competitive depth across the 300-rider field. Elite riders like Cole House and Ruth Sherman compete, but the emphasis stays recreational. Multiple distance options accommodate different skill levels without creating racing intensity. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As DocSavage puts it: "If the RD lets everyone know in the course description that there will be single track, rock on. It does separate those of us riding bigger tires, Maxxis Treadlites 2."

value.explanation: $120 includes post-race meal, beer token, DeFeet socks, and custom finisher prize — plus Liz M notes organizers provide gallon bags for personal supplies at aid stations. The weekend experience from brewery pickup to Stonehouse dinner stretches registration value across multiple venues.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-125. McCluskey's 4:45am start suggests overnight accommodation requirements, and South Williamsport isn't a budget destination. The Official FAQ recommends making 'a trip out of the full weekend,' which means lodging and dining costs beyond registration. Travel to central Pennsylvania adds expense without major airport convenience. Higher total cost than Badlands.

citations.label: worldwidecyclery.com: Open U P Wi De Force Eagle Axs Gravel Bike Rider Review

key_takeaways: Rider reviews and quotes: "This was my first time and I have to say, all the people that worked it were amazing and very friendly

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Is Iron Cross Gravel Race Too Hard?
videos.description:
Iron Cross XXI - North America's Original Gravel Race
Sun October 20, 2024
South Williamsport, PA

I asked racers at the 2023 edition of Iron Cross if they thought the race is too hard.

If you're not afraid, use the code: Friends-of-DirtWireTV 
to get $15 off your entry for Iron Cross 2024.
Register here:
https://www.bikereg.com/66039

videos.title: Why Are People Afraid of Iron Cross Gravel Race?
videos.description:
Iron Cross XXI - North America's Original Gravel Race
South Williamsport, PA

I asked racers at the 2023 edition of Iron Cross why they think people are afraid of this race.

Register for Iron Cross 2024 here:
https://www.bikereg.com/ironcross-2024
videos.transcript:
[Applause]
I don't know maybe Pennsylvania it's
kind of a scary place but it's a ton of
climbing in like 56 miles so there's
nowhere to hide you there's no sitting
in packs and Drafting and playing games
just you either either brought the legs
or you didn't uh L elevation and uh it's
pretty uh technical in some sections
it's got a little bit of everything kind

videos.curation_reason: Recent rider testimonials specifically addressing the race's reputation and challenging aspects with vivid course details.

quotes.text: It's a ton of climbing in like 56 miles so there's nowhere to hide - there's no sitting in packs and Drafting and playing games, just you either brought the legs or you didn't.

It's got a little bit of everything - road, gravel, soft pack, hike a bike. It definitely lives up to its reputation as far as being challenging but it also lives up to its reputation as far as having the best vibe.
About 10 miles ahead this is going to be what's called Larry's - Larry's tavern where we have to get off the bikes and do a hike a bike, that would be interesting.
